file_content.text: Go, Padawan. Please. If anything's happened to Qyzen....
Wait. Where is Qyzen? It's been... how long was I working?
I could go and find Qyzen, just to make sure he's alright.
Should I look for him?
Don't worry, Master Yuon. If anyone can take care of himself, it's Qyzen.
I'm sure he's fine.
While Qyzen's out there dawdling, the Fount of Rajivari could already have been breached.
I need that last coordinate!
Padawan, Qyzen is never late. Please, you must look for him.
He mentioned the waterfall caves. Didn't he? If Qyzen has the last coordinate, you can triangulate the Fount of Rajivari.
There's no time to waste, Padawan. Go. And may the Force be with you both.
Master Yuon? I have the clues we need.
Oh. Padawan? Back already? What clues did you find?
The terminals held the last words of Rajivari's apprentices....
I found ancient recordings.
I think I recovered enough of Rajivari's philosophy to help me....
Old teachings.
I got a few of Rajivari's sayings, and some scraps of history....
I don't know if it will help.
So the Jedi besieged Kaleth, after Rajivari tried to kill the Council. And his apprentices held the line, all by themselves. Remarkable.
I think I have everything I need. Should we focus on getting to the Fount of Rajivari?
What next, Master?
Yes, and when Qyzen brings us the final coordinate, you can....
Rajivari's apprentices knew there was no hope, but they defended their beliefs to the last.
They were brave, and loyal.
Yes. With a different master, they could have been great Jedi.
If preserving their master's ideas was so important, those apprentices should have done anything to survive.
They should have surrendered.
Perhaps they believed only one sort of life was worth living.
Hopefully the principles you've recovered will help you pass into the Fount of Rajivari safely. And once Qyzen brings us the last coordinate....
There's no need to tell the Council about those traps, Padawan. You understand.
Padawan, look. In the map's code--there's something else hidden here. A warning?
"The Fount of Rajivari has mechanisms for intruders. Only those who know Rajivari's path will walk through unscathed, to gain his wisdom."
Rajivari's philosophies are somehow the way past these mechanisms--likely traps.
So I must learn his path.
Mechanisms for intruders can only mean one thing.
It's talking about traps.
But according to this, knowledge of Rajivari's philosophy will protect you. Fascinating!
I'll take care of these mechanisms when I get there, Master Yuon.
I can handle that.
Rajivari was ruthless, Padawan, those traps will be fatal if you go unprepared.
We know Kaleth was Rajivari's stronghold. And excavators have uncovered ancient computer terminals in Upper Kaleth.
Those terminals might hold answers, if they weren't all locked with passwords.
The hilt of the first blade accessed the coordinates to the Fount of Rajivari. It could unlock these terminals, too.
The hilt I found could help.
Of course! Those engravings... some of them resemble security algorithms.
Is there anywhere else we could look?
Do we have any alternatives?
Nowhere I can think of. Those terminals would be our best hope....
Anyone who knew those passwords is long dead.
Then we're stuck.
Wait. We do have the first blade's hilt. It accessed the map; maybe it could access those terminals.
Go to Upper Kaleth, and investigate those terminals for any clue. I'll wait here for Qyzen. We're close, Padawan; I know it!
Master Yuon, I believe I have the coordinates for the Fount of Rajivari.
Qyzen mentioned as much--Padawan, I just received a very disturbing message. For you, from Nalen Raloch.
Survival. Mine, my village's, and yours, Jedi. Interesting to think about.
My people's deaths will be avenged. There's other paths to the Fount of Rajivari. I'll find it, and then I'll kill you.
You killed the villagers. How could you?
They attacked me. I didn't have a choice.
It was self-defense.
Let me see those coordinates, Padawan. I hope they're worth such a terrible price.
If I could change what happened, Master Yuon, I would.
I regret their deaths.
Then learn from this. It is the very least you can do for them!
If I'd let those villagers go, they would have returned later, in greater numbers.
They'd have kept pursuing me.
The future is ever-changing, Padawan. But those people are dead. That cannot be undone!
You fooled my people. It doesn't matter. There's other routes to the Fount of Rajivari. Interfere, and I'll kill you.
Nalen has truly fallen, then. And he wants you dead. You must be vigilant.
He may have found another route, but we're the ones with the map.
We're ahead in this race.
Yes, the coordinates. Please, let me see them.
There must be a way to save Nalen, Master, or reason with him.
I want to help him.
He may not give you the chance. You cannot risk yourself!
If it came to a battle between us, I know I would win.
I could defeat him easily.
No. Don't even consider it, this man is far too dangerous!
Yuon. Is alright.
We still have the Fount of Rajivari to find. Let me see those coordinates, Padawan; perhaps I can get us started.
I've studied similar depictions. And that coordinate matches ancient mappings of the eastern Tythos Ridge....
I think I understand the map.
Which fits with the first coordinate perfectly. Well done.
I can sense it's right, Master Yuon. So the second coordinate... must be the Tythos Ridge.
I feel we're getting close.
Yes, those fit exactly.
And I believe the second coordinate is the Tythos Ridge. Just visualize it from a climber's point of view.
We're looking at this wrong...
Which fits with the first coordinate perfectly. Well done.
Ah. Yes! There's truly no substitute for experience.
But that leaves... this coordinate. We can't triangulate the Fount of Rajivari without it. Perhaps it's a rock formation....
Hmm. Have seen like formations on hunts. Could scout waterfall caves, try to find.
That coordinate will give us the Fount of Rajivari. If you think you can find it, please hurry.
Do it. We're very close.
With two of us, the search would take half as long.
Should I go with you?
Stay. I know caves; is faster searching alone. Scorekeeper watch you.
If you want to wander through more cold, dank caves, be my guest.
Rather you than me.
Better than to stare at old thing forever. Scorekeeper watch you.
Qyzen knows those caves, Padawan. You can trust him to mind your back.
I deciphered a second clue from Rajivari's hologram. To find the Fount of Rajivari, this hilt must be taken to a cave in the Tythonian mountains.
The hologram says the founders meditated in that cave. Debated. They became the Jedi Council.
All our codes, our laws and principles, can be traced back to those debates.
The very first Council.
What should I do with the hilt when I arrive?
Did it have any other clues?
The hologram didn't say. Keep your eyes open.
They had no idea one of their number would eventually succumb to evil.
And Rajivari sat among them.
This cave I know. Is Flesh Raider cave now--good hunting. I would accompany.
I go ahead, make a good beginning before search for old things. Shall meet you, small hunter.
I apologize, Padawan. Qyzen's devotion to the hunt is quite... single-minded.
I don't mind. I welcome his help.
I'm not offended.
He seems to be a gifted hunter already.
Why is he so dedicated?
Hunting is part of Trandoshan religion and culture. Honing his skills is important.
I don't want his hunting interfering with my work.
I hope it won't be an issue.
It won't. And I suggest you don't call it "interference" to Qyzen's face.
Good luck, and be careful. The hologram said nothing of what might be waiting in those caves.
Rajivari's hologram proves the same technique existed. Don't you see? It'll resolve that silly debate, once and for all.
Yuon, is soft thing. Old, soft thing. Do not overexcite for this.
Overexcite. I'm not quite ready to--ah, Padawan!
Much longer and we'd have come looking for you. I thought you might have crossed paths with Nalen Raloch again.
Wherever Nalen is, he's not at Kaleth.
There was no sign of him.
How goes your hunting?
Good to see you, Qyzen.
Scorekeeper showed favor. And smiled on you also? So Yuon said.
Master Syo and Master Jaric met me outside. They wanted to discuss what you said, about me and the Force.
The Council delayed me.
Why are they distracting you? Your task is too important.
You said you found the first blade. Or its hilt, at least. Is it... may I see it?
Ah. The folds in the metal. The power cell chamber... these are lost techniques. Our lightsabers began here, with this.
I believe these etch marks are encoded information, Master Yuon.
It has data engraved on it.
And the interior's been modified too, perhaps to hold more.
It's incredible to be in the presence of something so old and influential.
Fascinating. And humbling.
Please, no encouraging. Already Yuon talks and talks of old things.
It's only junk.
Pay attention, Padawan.
The Fount of Rajivari. To think it might be real.
Evidence suggests Kaleth was destroyed in a great battle; old droids still walk those ruins today. But this "first blade" is a puzzle.
If it was once a fortress, it could refer to weapons that were stored in Kaleth.
Does Kaleth have an armory?
I can only think of one blade a Jedi would wield.
It must be a lightsaber.
Good deduction, but lightsabers had yet to be invented.
I can't help thinking Nalen's had much longer to work this out.
A puzzle Nalen is solving too.
We have found several old weapons in one section of Kaleth... nothing like a "first blade," but a good place to begin.
Ha. I planned your training so carefully. But the Force has intervened. Finding the Fount of Rajivari and stopping Nalen, must be... a greater test.
Are you saying the Force is guiding me?
What does that mean?
Sometimes the Force, not the Master, shapes a Padawan's trials. This seems to be such a time.
Even if the Force is shaping my training, I want your help, Master Yuon.
You're still my Master.
I... thank you.
Obviously, finding the Fount of Rajivari is more suited to my talents.
This is better than training.
You should know, Padawan. The Council tends to disapprove of such "training," but I'll explain everything to them.
For now, focus on exploring Kaleth for this "first blade." Call me on your holocommunicator at once if you have any success.
Padawan, I just spoke to Ranna Tao'Ven, the daughter of Kalikori village's matriarch, concerning your visit there.
I was appalled. Threatening innocent people is unacceptable. Aggression and impatience only lead to ruin.
I'm sorry, Master. I will try and remember.
I apologize.
We'll say no more of it for now. Let me see Rajivari's hologram.
I'm strong enough to shape my own path, Master Yuon.
I can cope.
Consider that strength is a function of power, and control. Now, let us examine Rajivari's hologram.
I want you to meditate on what you learned. Such experiences are what shape us as Jedi.
I will do so.
I found the holoprojector, as you asked.
We must discuss my mission.
We should check that Rajivari's hologram is safe.
All I did was speak to the villagers.
But it was trivial.
And we'll see what comes of it. Now, Rajivari's hologram.
The holoprojector was stolen by a Twi'lek, Nalen Raloch. He'd learned Force techniques from Rajivari's hologram--he was obviously unstable.
A villager? Very unusual. Then this Nalen is Force sensitive.... Let's see what he saw.
Activation protocol begins. A few words--shall this be all my legacy? No. My enemies are long dead. It is time.
Hear me. I have left true wisdom behind. For those who follow where the first blade points, from the sanctuary of the order. All else is fleeting....
My word. "True wisdom." Padawan, he... he's talking about the Fount of Rajivari.
What is this "Fount of Rajivari"?
Now I'm intrigued.
Master, you seem shaken.
Are you alright?
I--I'm fine. This is just... hard to believe.
Nothing Rajivari left behind can be safe.
That cannot be good.
After Rajivari fell, sources claimed he created a great archive of his knowledge and teachings. The Fount of Rajivari.
Generations of Jedi searched for it, finding nothing. The Fount's considered a hoax by all reputable scholars, but... we just heard proof.
It said to follow where the first blade points, from the sanctuary of the order. What sanctuary?
The hologram was giving clues.
Nalen Raloch saw this hologram, Master. More of Rajivari's knowledge could make him incredibly dangerous.
So did Nalen.
An untouched archive of ancient Jedi knowledge. Imagine what could be learned from it.
It must be very powerful.
The hologram said, follow where the first blade points, from the sanctuary of the order....
Kaleth! The ruins at Kaleth--the name means "sanctum." It's the remains of an ancient fortress.
Go to Kalikori village, and ask Bashenn about the holoprojector. I must do some reading; my Rajivari scholarship is rusty.
The thief is likely from Kalikori village. Local Twi'lek Pilgrims, here illegally; many of them are poor, or hungry.
Selling an ancient holoprojector could feed those villagers for months.
And Jedi relics are valuable.
Why are these Twi'leks here?
You called them "Pilgrims."
Religious persecution drove them from their homeworld. They've found sanctuary here, but without the Republic's permission.
You said Kalikori village isn't a legal settlement. I didn't think Tython had such laws.
Why is their village illegal?
The Republic couldn't give the Twi'leks permission to colonize Tython--too dangerous--but they came regardless.
I'd like you to go to Kalikori village, discover who took the holoprojector, and retrieve it. But, tread lightly.
The Twi'leks are here in defiance of Republic law. We're forbidden to fully defend them, even when the Flesh Raiders attack. Relations are... strained.
We're Jedi. Aren't we obligated to help those in need?
So we just do nothing?
This is the Jedi Council's judgment. I might disagree, but the decision is made.
Once the villagers understand the situation, I'm sure we can reach an accord.
I'll be diplomatic.
If the Twi'leks can't survive here without help, they should leave.
No one's forcing them to stay.
Tython is their home, Padawan. They have nowhere else to go.
When you reach Kalikori village, find Bashenn, captain of the village guard. He knows everyone, he may have seen the holoprojector.
I think meeting these Pilgrims will be a good lesson for you, Padawan. Go carefully.
There isn't. It's out of my hands, Qyzen.
"Out of hands. Can do nothing." From you, is strange to hear.
I haven't--Padawan. Come in. This is Qyzen Fess, an old friend. He's here on a hunting expedition; a sacred Trandoshan tradition.
Did you train Qyzen, too, Master Yuon?
Is he a Jedi?
Am no Jedi. Am hunter of beasts. And must scout, before light changes--Scorekeeper watch over.
It's an honor to meet you.
A pleasure, Qyzen.
Is welcome, small hunter. But have scouting, before light changes. Scorekeeper watch over.
This thing doesn't look like anybody's friend.
It's a freaky giant lizard.
Padawan! That is enough.
Is no matter. Have scouting, before light changes. Scorekeeper watch over, Yuon.
Some people, even some Jedi, disapprove of my friendship with Qyzen. I wanted you to meet, before rumors prejudiced you.
First, thank you for saving the holograms. The Jedi have lost enough lately without losing our history, too.
One of the holoprojectors was taken before I could reach it.
About the missing hologram.
I recall, and not just one at random, it seems. That hologram is of the infamous Master Rajivari.
I was glad to help, Master.
It was no trouble.
"Loss" is a small word for what we suffered at the Empire's hands.
You mean, in the war.
That discussion will have to wait.
I've identified the holoprojector that was stolen. It contained a hologram of... Master Rajivari.
Rajivari was another of the Jedi founders. He... turned to the dark side. He betrayed the very order he helped to create.
This Rajivari's betrayal paved the way for the Sith.
One of the first fallen Jedi.
What exactly did Rajivari do?
He betrayed the order? How?
Details of his life are maddeningly sparse.
Why would the founders keep Rajivari's image among them, after what he did?
Yet he had his own hologram.
Excellent question. To honor his previous contributions? Or a gesture of healing? Hmm.
Rajivari was immensely powerful. That stolen hologram could hold his darkest secrets.
